Overview Sample App Features User Sign-in Let your users sign in with public identity providers or your own identity system. Whether your users sign in or not, the User sign-in feature configures Amazon Cognito to uniquely identify the user and provide your app the appropriate credentials to access your AWS resources. The Sample App demonstrates assignment of a unique identifier for the user, the Amazon Cognito User ID. If optional or mandatory User Sign-in has been enabled in your project, then the Sample App also includes a sign-in screen, with a button for each configured sign-in provider. Powered by Amazon Cognito Demo User Identity App Analytics Collect app usage information and analyze key metrics. Amazon Mobile Analytics allows you to collect, visualize, and export app event data. You can track app usage and monetization in the Amazon Mobile Analytics console, or run custom analysis by automatically exporting app events to Amazon S3 and Amazon Redshift. The Sample App records user session activity in metrics that may be viewed in the Amazon Mobile Analytics console. It also provides buttons to demonstrate generating a custom or monetization event, which records user activity, such as the sale of an in-app purchase item. Powered by Amazon Mobile Analytics Demo App Analytics User Data Storage Store files for your users in the cloud.\nStore and sync user data in key/value pairs. Store user files such as photos in the cloud. Save user data in key/value pairs and sync across devices that are signed-in with the same user. The Sample App demonstrates User File Storage and User Profile Data. The User File Storage demonstration includes a remote file explorer, which allows you to upload and download files from your Amazon S3 bucket. You will have access to two folders, a public folder where files are accessible to all users and a private folder where files are only accessible by the current app user.\n\nThe User Profile Data demonstration stores an app color theme using Amazon Cognito Sync and synchronizes that data across all of the user\'s devices as key/value pairs. Powered by Amazon Cognito and Amazon S3 Demo User File Storage Demo User Profile Data Push Notifications Send push notifications to individuals or groups of users. Receive push notifications on your device and subscribe to topics you have created. The Sample App allows you to register to receive push notifications, and it provides checkboxes to demonstrate subscribing to receive messages from your configured Amazon SNS topics. Powered by Amazon SNS Demo Push Notifications Cloud Logic Run backend code in the cloud. Run backend code in the cloud. The Sample App demonstrates the ability of a mobile app to invoke an AWS Lambda function. Enter the name of the function you wish to run and provide a list of request inputs. Invoke the function and see results. Powered by AWS Lambda Demo Cloud Logic User Identity Keep track of users Displays the user identity. If your connection is weak, this may take some time Please wait … Loading… Please choose a theme: NoSQL Database Store data in the cloud. Store data in the cloud. The Sample App demonstrates how to access your configured Amazon DynamoDB NoSQL database tables. Select your table, insert sample data, and perform queries by choosing from a list of examples. Hold down an item in query results to update or delete the item. When you\'re done with the demo, you can remove the sample data from your table. Powered by Amazon DynamoDB

Uploading your record to the online server Added your record to the database Error. Please try again. Please complete your migraine record Migraine Tree Your migraine can\'t end before it started! Get better soon! delete update Records current task Migraine severity prediction: pain source: pain type: length: Average Migraine: 1 to 10 Migraine Summary Migraine length: Pain at peak: Weather: View Anyone who knows someone or suffers from migraines themselves can attest to how debilitating this neurological disorder can be. This app is a prototype designed for the Birkbeck College Master\'s of Computer Science project with the goal to help track and predict migraine severity to allow users a better understanding of their migraines and be able to make an informed decision as to when to take medication.\nData is collected on migraine triggers and weather conditions which is saved locally on the device and on Amazon Web Services DynamoDB.\nThis data is anonymous and no personal data is collected.\nData will be used to design a new migraine predictive model and then subsequently deleted.
